questions.questionText: An applicant is seeking admission to a Master’s program (MSc). This applicant happens to have influential parents. Now, you, as an admissions committee member, are faced with a decision: Should this applicant be given a position that has become available due to another student declining their offer?
answers: You evaluate the applicant based on their qualifications and merit alone.
You consider the applicant's qualifications and merit but also take into account any potential connections.
You automatically reject the applicant because of their influential parents.
You favor the applicant solely because of their influential parents.

questions.questionText: You want to purchase an equipment that is not budgeted. What do you do?
answers: You buy the equipment from the other allocated funds.
You write a case for it and request for additional funds.
You submit a proposal revising the allocated budget to accommodate the equipment.
You don’t buy the equipment.

questions.questionText: You formulated a survey and circulated the survey. After a day, once you already have a few responses, you modify the survey. What will you do with your findings?
answers: You ask the previous respondents to redo the survey.
You only keep the new responses.
You don't remove any responses and inform the team about the changes made.
You keep all the responses but make a note of the date you make the changes as well as mention what the changes were.

questions.questionText: You are writing a paper for submission to a journal and your P.I. asks you to add a name to the author section, of someone who did not contribute to the paper. What will you do?
answers: You publish the paper without the P.I.
Ask the PI for an explanation.
Add the name of the author.
Meet the person whose name is to be added and discuss the situation.

questions.questionText: You discover a case of sexual harassment accidentally. What do you do?
answers: You yell and inform them of your presence.
Call someone (e.g., security, supervisor) to address the situation.
Make a record of the incident, including details and context.
Report the incident to the appropriate authorities.
